## What does reproducibility mean actually? {auto-animate="true"}

<br/>

::: fragment
-   [**Direct reproducibility**]{.nice-green} (also called *experimental reproducibility*) :test_tube:
:::

::: fragment
-   [**Analytical reproducibility**]{.nice-green} (also called *computational reproducibility*) :computer:
:::

<br/>

::: fragment
Other related terms to distinguish:
:::

::: fragment
-   **Replicability**: *Different data* \| Same analysis methods
-   **Robustness**: Same data \| *Different analysis methods*
-   **Generalisability**: Different data \| *Different analysis methods*
:::

::: aside
<ul style="list-style: none; font-size: 75%">

<li>Schloss, 2018. DOI: [10.1128/mbio.00525-18](https://doi.org/10.1128/mbio.00525-18)</li>

## Why are we talking about this now?

<!-- We need to have confidence that our research is good quality and we are doing good science. -->

:::::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
![Baker, M. 1,500 scientists lift the lid on reproducibility. Nature 533, 452–454 (2016). DOI: [10.1038/533452a](https://doi.org/10.1038/533452a).](images/nature-reproducibility-crisis.png){.lightbox width="700" style="max-width: 90vw; max-height: 90vh;" fig-align="center"}
:::

<!-- ![Baker, M. 1,500 scientists lift the lid on reproducibility. Nature 533, 452–454 (2016). DOI:  [10.1038/533452a](https://doi.org/10.1038/533452a).](images/donut_chart_fixed.png){.lightbox fig-align="center" width="1200"} -->

:::: {.column width="50%"}
<br/>

::: incremental
-   70% of researchers can't reproduce others' findings

-   60% can't reproduce **their own findings**

-   Non-reproducible biomedical research costs \$28 billion/year<br />([Freedman et al. 2015](https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pbio.1002165))
:::
::::
::::::

<!-- ## What interest behind doing reproducible research<br />can you think of? :thinking: {style="text-align: center;"} -->

## How important is it? [Well, quite important]{.fragment}

</br> </br>

<!-- In addition to basic scientific rigour, working reproducibly is hugely valuable, because: -->

::: incremental
-   Anyone (with a similar level of skills) should be able to do reproduce your research and benefit from it
-   Funders (e.g., ANR) and journals now require data and code accessibility, which aligns with the growing open-science movement
-   ~~If I keep my data and code, I have a competitive advantage~~
-   If I share my data and code, my work will gain more visibility (and citations :sunglasses:)
:::

## Advantages

</br> </br>

::: incremental
-   It obliges you to verify your work (by sharing both docs, data and code)
-   [**Your future self**]{.nice-green} will thank you (you'll be much more productive)
-   Your collaborators too
-   By ensuring reproducibility, you reinforce your credibility and reputation
-   Employers increasingly value reproducible research skills
-   Reproducibility fosters [**trust**]{.nice-green} in scientific progress and [**accelerates**]{.nice-green} it

<!-- 
It speeds progress in science by allowing you (or others) to rapidly build on previous findings and analyses
It allows easy comparison of new analytical approaches (methods, models, etc) to older ones
It makes it easy to repeat the same analyses when new data are collected or added
Most skills and software used in Reproducible Research are very useful beyond Reproducible Research alone!
Reproducible research skills are highly sought after in careers like data science etc…
-->
:::

```{r}
# penguin_analysis.R
# Author: Your Name
# Purpose: Summarise bill length across species in `palmerpenguins` dataset
# Date: 2025-09-22

# ---- Load packages ----
library(dplyr)
library(palmerpenguins)

# ---- Summarise bill length by species ----
bill_length_summary_df <- penguins |>
  group_by(species) |>
  summarise(mean_bill_length_mm = mean(bill_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE))
```

<hr class="nice-green-obj" style="border: 2px solid; margin: 20px 0;">

::: {style="margin-top: 1em;"}
[**Issues**]{.nice-pink}: Without proper coding practices, analyses become error-prone, impossible to reproduce, and difficult for others (including your future self) to understand or verify
:::

:::::::: {style="margin-top: 1em;"}
:::::: columns
:::: {.column width="50%"}
[**Solutions**]{.nice-green}:

-   Use reproducible environments
-   Document your code
-   Harmonise your code style
::::

:::: {.column width="50%"}
```{r}
#| echo: true
#| output: false
#| eval: false
#| code-line-numbers: "8-9"

# Variable name is way too descriptive
mean_of_penguins_bill_length_in_millimeters_for_all_islands <- mean(penguins$bill_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE)

# Variable name too cryptic
x <- mean(penguins$bill_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE)

# A better option
bill_length_mean_mm <- mean(penguins$bill_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE)
```

## Take-home messages

::: {style="font-size: 70%;"}
> Reproducible research is a process, not a destination
:::

::: incremental
- Start small: pick one practice and build habits
- Perfect is the enemy of good
- The goal: better collaboration, scientific rigor, and trust in science
- To advance, we must code a little...
:::
